<!-- # Geospatial analysis: additional layers -->

## Introduction

Until now, we have learnt general concepts about geospatial visualization in independent lessons. The **modular** approach of `{ggplot2}` allows to successively add all of them in different **layers**.

However, these enriched thematic maps also require to contain **text** and **labels** referring to specific places or regions, and important map elements like **scale bars** and a **north arrow**, as will be illustrated in this part.

![Figure 1. Ggplot map with multiple layers.](images/multilayer_map_01.png){width="408"}

In this lesson, we will learn to use functions from the `{ggspatial}` and `{ggsflabel}` packages to add all of these additional elements to our maps!

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

## Learning objectives

1.  Access **hospital** data coordinates using the `{afrihealthsites}` package.

2.  Add text and **labels** to ggplot maps using the `{ggsflabel}` package.

3.  Add arrow and scale **annotations** in ggplot maps using the `{ggspatial}` package.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

### Add a Scale bar and North arrow with `{ggspatial}` {.unnumbered}

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Let's use `{ggspatial}` with a `{ggplot}` map:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `annotation_north_arrow()` adds a north symbol, and

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `annotation_scale()` a scale bar.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r world-scale-north, message = TRUE}
ggplot() +
  
  # country map
  geom_sf(data = sierra_leone) +
  
  # hospital points
  geom_sf(data = sle_healthsites_set) +
  
  # map annotations
         (       ) + # ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
         (       ) +
  
  # map extent
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-13.5,-12.7), ylim = c(8.0,8.7))
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ **location** are by default in the bottom left (`"bl"`)

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `location` uses `"tr"` for top right, `"bl"` for bottom left, etc.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: practice
To this `ggplot` map with the `zimbabwe_adm1` object:

Add a Scale bar located in the `bottom right` of the map, and a North arrow in the `top left`.

```{r,eval = FALSE}
q4 <- 
  zimbabwe_adm1 %>% 
  ggplot() + 
  geom_sf() +
  _________ +
  _________
q4
```

```{r,include=FALSE}
.check_q4()
.hint_q4()
```
:::

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: side-note

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ The [North arrow style](https://paleolimbot.github.io/ggspatial/reference/north_arrow_orienteering.html) can be adjusted with `style`.

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ [scale distance](https://paleolimbot.github.io/ggspatial/reference/annotation_scale.html) is set to `"km"` by default, also in "m", "cm", "mi", "ft", or "in".
:::

### Add hospital names with `geom_sf_text_repel()` {.unnumbered}

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `geom_sf_text()` to add hospital locations and names as text:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r cities-plot}
sle_healthsites_set %>% 
  ggplot() +
  # geometry
  geom_sf() +
  # label
  geom_sf_text(mapping = aes(label= facility_name)) # ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ This is not really satisfactory, 

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ names overlap on the points, 

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ not easy to read on the background. 

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ [`{ggsflabel}`](https://yutannihilation.github.io/ggsflabel/index.html) inspired in `{ggrepel}` 

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ deal with label placement in `ggplot` maps with `sf` objects 

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ including automated movement of labels in case of overlap.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `geom_sf_text_repel` and `geom_sf_label_repel`

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ We "nudge" `facility_name` away, and connect them to the city locations:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r cities-plot-nudge}
sle_healthsites_set %>% 
  ggplot() +
  # geometry
  geom_sf() +
  # label
           (         ) # ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: practice
`zimbabwe_hospitals` contains all the `hospital` facilities of `Zimbabwe`:

```{r,eval=FALSE}
zimbabwe_hospitals <- 
  afrihealthsites(country = 'Zimbabwe', 
                  datasource='healthsites',
                  plot = FALSE) %>% 
  filter(amenity == 'hospital')

zimbabwe_hospitals
```

Add the name of these facilities as text without overlaps using the `geom_sf_text_repel()` function.

```{r,eval = FALSE}
q5 <- 
  zimbabwe_hospitals %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_sf() +
  ____________
q5
```

```{r,include=FALSE}
.check_q5()
.hint_q5()
```
:::

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ We can use [`{ggrepel}` arguments](https://ggrepel.slowkow.com/articles/examples.html) to improve its output:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ The size (argument `size`);

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ The type of font (`fontface`);

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ The force of repulsion between overlapping text labels (`force`);

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ The additional padding around the each text label (`box.padding`).

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r}
sle_healthsites_set %>% 
  ggplot() +
  # geometry
  geom_sf() +
  # label
  geom_sf_text_repel(mapping = aes(label= facility_name),
                     size = 2,         # ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
                     fontface = "bold",
                     force = 40, 
                     box.padding = 0.6)
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Adding this layer to the current map, we obtain:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r}
ggplot() +
  
  # country map
  geom_sf(data = sierra_leone) +
  
  # hospital points 
  geom_sf(data = sle_healthsites_set) +         
  # hospital names with repelled text 
  geom_sf_text_repel(data = sle_healthsites_set,         # ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
                     mapping = aes(label = facility_name),
                     size         = 2,
                     fontface     = "bold",
                     force        = 0.5,
                     box.padding  = 0.6,
                     nudge_x      = -0.25,
                     direction    = "y",
                     hjust        = 1,
                     segment.size = 0.2) +
  
  # map annotation
  annotation_north_arrow(location="tl") +
  annotation_scale(location="bl") +
  
  # map extent
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-13.5,-12.7), 
           ylim = c(8.0,8.7))
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r states}
  # province labels
```

```{r,eval = FALSE}
q2
```

```{r states-nudge}
                     segment.size = 0.2) +
```

## Final map

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Let's put everything together:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Adding district boundaries filled by area, and field sited recorded by a GPS device:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r, message=FALSE,warning=FALSE}
# districts
sierra_leone_shp <- 
  sf::read_sf(here("basic_geospatial_viz/data/boundaries/sle_adm3.shp")) %>% 
  filter(admin1Name=="Western")

# field site points
sites_sf <- readr::read_csv(
  here("basic_geospatial_viz/data/gps_healthsites.csv")) %>% 
  st_as_sf(coords = c("gps_longitude","gps_latitude"), crs = 4326)
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r,fig.width=8,fig.height=7}
ggplot() +
  
  # country map
  geom_sf(data = sierra_leone) +
  
  # districts filled by area
  geom_sf(data = sierra_leone_shp, # ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
          mapping = aes(fill = area_km2)) +
  # color scale for fill
  scale_fill_continuous_sequential(palette="Reds 3", 
                                   alpha = 0.8) +
  # field site points
  geom_sf(data = sites_sf,              # ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
          mapping = aes(color = gps_name),
          shape = 18, size = 4) +
  
  # province names with repelled labels
  geom_sf_label_repel(data = sierra_leone %>% 
                        filter(shapeName!="Eastern"),
                      mapping = aes(label=shapeName)) +
  
  # hospital points 
  geom_sf(data = sle_healthsites_set) +         
  # hospital names with repelled text 
  geom_sf_text_repel(data = sle_healthsites_set,
                     mapping = aes(label = facility_name),
                     size         = 2,
                     fontface     = "bold",
                     force        = 0.5,
                     box.padding  = 0.6,
                     nudge_x      = -0.25,
                     direction    = "y",
                     hjust        = 1,
                     segment.size = 0.2) +
  
  # map annotation
  annotation_north_arrow(location="tl") +
  annotation_scale(location="bl") +
  
  # map extent
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-13.5,-12.7), 
           ylim = c(8.0,8.7)) +
  
  # ggplot labels
  labs(x = "Longitude",
       y = "Latitude",
       fill = expression(Area~km^2),
       color = "GPS data",
       title = "How are Tier 3 Hospitals distributed in the Western Province of Sierra Leone?")
```

## Wrap up

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Adding **layers** on `ggplot2` is relatively straightforward, 

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ as long as the data is properly stored in an `sf` object. 

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Adding additional layers like point or polygon **labels** and **map annotations** would simply follow the same logic, 

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ with additional calls *after* `geom_sf()` and at the *right place* in the `ggplot2` sequence.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)
